"ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a sad state of affairs when the fact that a rock & roll album recorded live, with minimal overdubs, is considered worth highlighting, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s notable that the new full-length from Thomas Wynn & the Believers was recorded Ã¢â‚¬Å“as live as possible.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Had Wynn reshaped his band Ã¢â‚¬â€œ one of the most incandescent beacons of rock & roll classicism in Orlando Ã¢â‚¬â€œ into some Pro Tools-contorted beast, the resulting work wouldÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been not only a disservice to the transcendent nature of their live performances, it wouldÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve also been profoundly disappointing and dishonest. Yet, thanks to a simple and straightforward approach to the recording process, Brothers and Sisters is full of buzzing, open-chord goodness, crackling harmonies and visceral energy to spare. 

"What Wynn and the Believers deliver is a sly bit of surprise. Their workmanlike ethos and general ubiquity Ã¢â‚¬â€œ seldom a week goes by without a gig of some sort Ã¢â‚¬â€œ has likely lulled local scene-watchers into thinking they know exactly what the deal is here: classic rock delivered with roof-raising spirit and a crowd-friendly smile. But there are also subtle variations on the 40-year-old form, tweaks that are much more recognizable on record than on stage. 

"For instance, the title track unfolds gradually and gracefully into a CCR-quoting number that seems like an awfully unoriginal way to begin a record. However, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Brothers and SistersÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ reveals itself as much more complex, using a Fogerty riff as little more than a launchpad for a soulful, cathartic and completely original rocker. 

"ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s that soulfulness that continues to set WynnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s band apart from many road-dogging young classic-rock acts. Live, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the grit in WynnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s voice, the generosity of his spirit and the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s visible camaraderie that helps to elevate the BelieversÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ music beyond mundane recitations of worn-out Ã¢â‚¬â„¢60s rock tropes. On the album, thanks to the live-to-tape ethos of the sessions, all of that comes across beautifully." Jason Ferguson/Orlando Weekly
